content.p: The task list above encapsulates what needs to be accomplished in this activity.
As you complete each item, it will be checked off by the program.
Select a region for an earthquake from the list above, then click the Trigger Earthquake button.
If the Journal is not visible on the left, click its tab.
Scroll down to the data table.
Complete the table by using the tools above.
Click a tool and the "Instruction" will give you a description of its use. The "Help" tool (?) will offer more details.
Click a tool and the "Instruction" will give you a description of its use. The "Help" tool (?) will offer more details.
Use your mouse on the seismogram to click and drag the S-P lag time.
Be sure to record your results in the data table of your journal.
Click and drag to measure the maximum amplitude of the S-wave.
Drag on the curve to determine the epicentral distance for each S-P lag time.
Click on each seismic station and drag out an epicentral circle with the appropriate distance as radius.
These circles should intersect close to a single point.
Click on the map and drag the little "E" to the point that represents the epicenter of this earthquake.
Estimate the latitude and longitude values of the location of the earthquake's epicenter and record these values in your journal.
Determine the Richter Magnitude for each station by dragging the ends of the red line on the NOMOGRAM to match the S-P lag times and the S-wave amplitudes.
Record these values in your journal.
Your Latitude and Longitude values differ significantly for the actual ones.
Check to be sure your determination is correct and if it is, then verify your S-P lag times and associated distances.
You've correctly located the epicenter.
You may want to print and/or save your journal, nomogram, or the map.
You can quit by clicking on the quit button.
Your average magnitude value differs significantly for the actual one.
Check to be sure your determination is correct and if it is, then verify your amplitudes and associated distances.
